data.title: Phot.Helgoland.Gull.01.060929.9578.jpg
data.meta_description:
Germany, Helgoland/Heligoland
	‚Ä¶at about 40 meters above sea level,
	...a seagull with a fear of heights, or plastic in the sea?...üòï
	
	Helgoland, ‚ÄúThe Red Rock‚Äù, a small German sedimentary rock archipelago in the German Bay in the North Sea.
	Formerly in Danish & British possessions, Britain gave up the islands to Germany in 1890 in the Heligoland-Zanzibar Treaty. The islands, approximately population 1,650, are located in the Helgoland Bight, part of the German Bight, in the south-eastern corner of the North Sea. Heligoland is the only German offshore island 70 km away from the mainland, approximately two hours' sailing time from Cuxhaven at the mouth of the River Elbe, three hours from Hamburg with a high-speed catamaran ferry.
	
	Heligoland is particularly well known among bird lovers, the enormous background noise of the birds is impressive from spring to late summer.
	In addition, due to its isolated location, the island is very convenient as a resting place for many migratory birds and becomes a real hotspot for biodiversity in spring & autumn. Ocean birds can also be observed regularly. In recent years black-browed albatross, which is actually native to the southern hemisphere, has even visited the island. Migratory birds uses Helgoland as resting place in fall & spring.
	
	On Germany's only bird rock, the Heligoland "Lummenfelsen", the nesting, behaviour & breeding space of a sea bird colony with around 10,000 pairs of birds can be observed every year from March to September. Five bird species breed exclusively on Heligoland.
	In addition to the guillemot that gives the rock its name, these are gannets, fulmar, kittiwakes & razorbills.
	The northern gannet is the most conspicuous of the species mentioned. With its cream-colored head, black wing tips and otherwise white plumage, it is unmistakable. It first settled on Heligoland as a breeding bird in 1991, now over 1000 pairs are breeding in Lummenfelsen & on the Lange Anna, from March to September, the last young birds leave the cliffs in early to mid-October
	
	The largest colonies forming; 
	‚àö - Trottellummen, common guillemot have fast direct flight but are not very agile. They are more manoeuvrable underwater, typically diving to depths of 30‚Äì60 mtr depths of up to 180 mtr have been recorded. 
	
	They breed in colonies at high densities & make no nest; their single egg is incubated on a bare rock ledge on a cliff face. Eggs hatch after 30 days incubation. The chick is born downy & can regulate its body temperature after 10 days. Some 20 days after hatching the chick leaves its nesting ledge & heads for the sea, unable to fly, but gliding for some distance with fluttering wings, accompanied by its male parent, chicks are capable of diving as soon as they hit the water. The female stays at the nest site for some 14 days after the chick has left. 
	
	‚àö - Eissturmv√∂gel, northern fulmar or Arctic fulmar is a highly abundant seabird found primarily in subarctic regions of the North Atlantic & North Pacific oceans. Fulmars come in one of two colours, a light one with white head & body, grey wings & tail: a dark one which is uniformly grey. 
	
	‚àö - Dreizehenm√∂we
	A "Dreizehenm√∂wen", literally meaning "three toes gulls", the genus name the specific tridactyla is from Ancient Greek tridaktulos, "three-toed", from tri-, "three" & daktulos, "toe".
	The English name is derived from its call, a shrill 'kittee-wa-aaake, kitte-wa-aaake'. 
	In North America, this species is known as the black-legged kittiwake to differentiate it from the red-legged kittiwake, but in Europe, where it is the only member of the genus, it is often known just as kittiwake.
	The kittiwakes are the loudest of all, in flight they are particularly easy to recognize by their black wing tips.
	They emerge from the North Atlantic as early as March, until April the colony is finally fully occupied with over 9,000.
	They build their nests of seaweed, algae & grass on small rock ledges, usually they lay only two eggs.
	In July / August the young birds spontaneously rise into the air & at the beginning of September the rock is finally completely cleared again, until the coming year, when everything the spectacular start all over again.
	
	‚àö - Basst√∂lpel
	Gannets, the Name Basst√∂lpel originated from the Gannets Colonies on the Bass Rocks on the East Coast of Scotland, Heligoland is the only breeding place in Germany for this Birds.
	
	‚àö - Tordalk, 
	razorbill, razor-billed auk, is a colonial seabird in the monotypic genus Alca of the family Alcidae, the auks. & closest living relative of the extinct great auk, even if it looks like the penguins, it is not related to them. even if it looks like the penguins, it is not related to them.
	Razorbills are primarily black with a white underside. The male and female are identical in plumage; however, males are generally larger than females. This agile bird, which is capable of both flight & diving, has a predominantly aquatic lifestyle, they only comes to land in order to breed & is monogamous, choosing one partner for life. Females lay one egg per year.
	
	üìå üëâ üëâ The greatest danger for the seabirds is not the jump of the Border from the ‚ÄúThe Red Rock‚Äù from a height of 40 mtr to 60 mtr into the sea or other enemies like robben etc, it is the plastic of all kind floating in & on the water.
	The birds are entangled in the fractions of nets, bags & especially the coloured cords, which they also bring to their nesting places, they get strangled or suffocate because they consider it food.
	
	üëâ One World one Dream,
	üôè...Danke, Xi√®xie Ë∞¢Ë∞¢, Thanks, Gracias, Merci, Grazie, Obrigado, Arigat√¥, Dhanyavad, Chokrane to you & over
	16 million visits in my photostream with countless motivating comments
data.text:
Germany, Helgoland/Heligoland

‚Ä¶at about 40 meters above sea level,

...a seagull with a fear of heights, or plastic in the sea?...üòï

Helgoland, ‚ÄúThe Red Rock‚Äù, a small German sedimentary rock archipelago in the German Bay in the North Sea.

Formerly in Danish & British possessions, Britain gave up the islands to Germany in 1890 in the Heligoland-Zanzibar Treaty. The islands, approximately population 1,650, are located in the Helgoland Bight, part of the German Bight, in the south-eastern corner of the North Sea. Heligoland is the only German offshore island 70 km away from the mainland, approximately two hours' sailing time from Cuxhaven at the mouth of the River Elbe, three hours from Hamburg with a high-speed catamaran ferry.

Heligoland is particularly well known among bird lovers, the enormous background noise of the birds is impressive from spring to late summer.

In addition, due to its isolated location, the island is very convenient as a resting place for many migratory birds and becomes a real hotspot for biodiversity in spring & autumn. Ocean birds can also be observed regularly. In recent years black-browed albatross, which is actually native to the southern hemisphere, has even visited the island. Migratory birds uses Helgoland as resting place in fall & spring.

On Germany's only bird rock, the Heligoland "Lummenfelsen", the nesting, behaviour & breeding space of a sea bird colony with around 10,000 pairs of birds can be observed every year from March to September. Five bird species breed exclusively on Heligoland.

In addition to the guillemot that gives the rock its name, these are gannets, fulmar, kittiwakes & razorbills.

The northern gannet is the most conspicuous of the species mentioned. With its cream-colored head, black wing tips and otherwise white plumage, it is unmistakable. It first settled on Heligoland as a breeding bird in 1991, now over 1000 pairs are breeding in Lummenfelsen & on the Lange Anna, from March to September, the last young birds leave the cliffs in early to mid-October

The largest colonies forming;

‚àö - Trottellummen, common guillemot have fast direct flight but are not very agile. They are more manoeuvrable underwater, typically diving to depths of 30‚Äì60 mtr depths of up to 180 mtr have been recorded.

They breed in colonies at high densities & make no nest; their single egg is incubated on a bare rock ledge on a cliff face. Eggs hatch after 30 days incubation. The chick is born downy & can regulate its body temperature after 10 days. Some 20 days after hatching the chick leaves its nesting ledge & heads for the sea, unable to fly, but gliding for some distance with fluttering wings, accompanied by its male parent, chicks are capable of diving as soon as they hit the water. The female stays at the nest site for some 14 days after the chick has left.

‚àö - Eissturmv√∂gel, northern fulmar or Arctic fulmar is a highly abundant seabird found primarily in subarctic regions of the North Atlantic & North Pacific oceans. Fulmars come in one of two colours, a light one with white head & body, grey wings & tail: a dark one which is uniformly grey.

‚àö - Dreizehenm√∂we

A "Dreizehenm√∂wen", literally meaning "three toes gulls", the genus name the specific tridactyla is from Ancient Greek tridaktulos, "three-toed", from tri-, "three" & daktulos, "toe".

The English name is derived from its call, a shrill 'kittee-wa-aaake, kitte-wa-aaake'.

In North America, this species is known as the black-legged kittiwake to differentiate it from the red-legged kittiwake, but in Europe, where it is the only member of the genus, it is often known just as kittiwake.

The kittiwakes are the loudest of all, in flight they are particularly easy to recognize by their black wing tips.

They emerge from the North Atlantic as early as March, until April the colony is finally fully occupied with over 9,000.

They build their nests of seaweed, algae & grass on small rock ledges, usually they lay only two eggs.

In July / August the young birds spontaneously rise into the air & at the beginning of September the rock is finally completely cleared again, until the coming year, when everything the spectacular start all over again.

‚àö - Basst√∂lpel

Gannets, the Name Basst√∂lpel originated from the Gannets Colonies on the Bass Rocks on the East Coast of Scotland, Heligoland is the only breeding place in Germany for this Birds.

‚àö - Tordalk,

razorbill, razor-billed auk, is a colonial seabird in the monotypic genus Alca of the family Alcidae, the auks. & closest living relative of the extinct great auk, even if it looks like the penguins, it is not related to them. even if it looks like the penguins, it is not related to them.

Razorbills are primarily black with a white underside. The male and female are identical in plumage; however, males are generally larger than females. This agile bird, which is capable of both flight & diving, has a predominantly aquatic lifestyle, they only comes to land in order to breed & is monogamous, choosing one partner for life. Females lay one egg per year.

üìå üëâ üëâ The greatest danger for the seabirds is not the jump of the Border from the ‚ÄúThe Red Rock‚Äù from a height of 40 mtr to 60 mtr into the sea or other enemies like robben etc, it is the plastic of all kind floating in & on the water.

The birds are entangled in the fractions of nets, bags & especially the coloured cords, which they also bring to their nesting places, they get strangled or suffocate because they consider it food.

üëâ One World one Dream,

üôè...Danke, Xi√®xie Ë∞¢Ë∞¢, Thanks, Gracias, Merci, Grazie, Obrigado, Arigat√¥, Dhanyavad, Chokrane to you & over

16 million visits in my photostream with countless motivating comments
